attributes.title: Effect of Noninvasive Electrical Brain Stimulation on Memory Performance at Different Times of Day in Younger and Older Adults

q1.value: Effect of Noninvasive Electrical Brain Stimulation on Memory Performance at Different Times of Day in Younger and Older Adults

q2.value: Gabriella V Hirsch, David A Gallo, Taylor Chamberlain, Gabriella Hirsch

q3.value: Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS) is a safe and accessible, non-invasive brain stimulation technique for testing causal links between different brain regions and functions.  However, the effectiveness of single-trial tDCS to manipulate higher-order cognitive functions, such as memory, is in question. This study will investigate the extent to which 20 minutes of anodal tDCS to left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (dlPFC), relative to a sham stimulation condition, impacts recollection accuracy and working memory performance as a function of time-of-day in younger and older adults. We also will include an active parietal stimulation control in younger adults. Moreover, this study will test the extent that tDCS to dlPFC impacts memory performance by modulating impacting information-specific processes and/or cognitive control processes that operate across different types of information, thereby informing basic theories of how dlPFC contributes to memory in younger and older adults.

q4.value:
1.  Younger Adults Primary Hypothesis: dlPFC tDCS/Sham X AM/PM. We hypothesize that tDCS benefits may be larger during suboptimal times of cognitive function. For younger adults, we predict that tDCS of the dlPFC will improve episodic memory accuracy and working memory, relative to sham tDCS or active parietal tDCS. We also predict larger tDCS benefits during the AM than PM session (i.e., the suboptimal time of cognitive function for many younger adults).

2. Older Adults Primary Hypothesis: dlPFC tDCS/Sham X AM/PM. We predict that tDCS of the dlPFC will improve episodic memory accuracy and working memory in older adults, relative to sham tDCS, with larger benefits during the PM session than the AM session (i.e., the suboptimal time of cognitive function for many older adults). 

3. Owl-Lark Hypotheses: tDCS effects may be moderated by time of day preferences, so in secondary analyses of tDCS effects we will assess tDCS effects as a function of an individual’s optimal time of processing (measured by self-report and wrist accelerometry) instead of age group. We predict larger tDCS benefits during suboptimal times of processing.

4. Task-based Hypotheses: To the extent that tDCS boosts memory by improving cognitively controlled processes, high difficulty items should benefit more from tDCS than low difficulty items on each memory task. To the extent that tDCS to left dlPFC boosts verbal/conceptual processing more than pictorial/visuospatial processing, the former should benefit more from tDCS than the latter.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The stimulation condition (tDCS active vs. sham) is manipulated between-subjects, while time of testing (AM/PM) is manipulated within-subjects, and age (younger, older) is between-subjects. 50 Younger Adults will be randomly assigned to each of three between-subjects tDCS conditions (left prefrontal active stimulation, left parietal active stimulation, left sham stimulation (½ prefrontal, ½ partietal), total YA n=150) and 50 cognitively normal older adults will be randomly assigned to each of two between-subject tDCS conditions (left prefrontal active, left sham prefrontal, total OA n=100). Each participant will complete 3 sessions: orientation/baseline (no tDCS, time of day not controlled), AM tDCS, PM tDCS (counterbalancing the order of the AM and PM sessions). 

Randomization will be stratified by age group (younger versus older adults). Following the baseline assessment, each participant will be randomized to either AM -> PM or PM -> AM for their subsequent testing sessions. Upon arriving for the first testing session, each participant will be randomly assigned to one of 12 counterbalancing conditions designed to ensure that memory task conditions are balanced across participants and are not confounded with session order (see below for task counterbalancing). At that point, stratified randomization (i.e., within strata based on age, AM -> PM versus PM -> AM and testing condition) will be used to assign treatment (i.e., tDCS versus sham). Treatment selection at the time of administration will be performed by entering a unique numeric code assigned at the time of randomization, thereby blinding both the participant and the administrator(s) to the treatment (i.e., double-blind). Due to the stratified randomization scheme, the number of participants randomized to each treatment group might vary slightly, thus we will continue recruitment until a minimum of 50 participants in each group has been reached. Additional participants will be recruited in case of dropout to ensure 50 participants complete the study in each group. 

Within the episodic memory task, we will manipulate (within-subjects): the format of to-be-remembered studied materials (i.e. words or pictures), crossed with the difficulty of the items (via study repetition:  once or twice). To ensure that performance is in intermediate ranges for both age groups, thereby allowing sensitivity for tDCS effects, we will use a slower presentation rate for older adults than younger adults. Within the working memory task, we will manipulate (within-subjects): the format kind of the studied to-be-remembered materials (i.e. verbal or, visuospatial), crossed with the difficulty of the items (2-back and 3-back for younger adults, 1-back and 2-back for older adults).  

Each subject is also randomized to a memory task counterbalancing condition that determines which version of the episodic and working memory tasks they receive. For the episodic task, three versions were created, each using different subsets of stimuli, and these versions counterbalanced across the three testing sessions to ensure that testing session order was not confounded with the stimuli used in the memory task used. The order of the encoding task conditions (eg, word/picture) also is counterbalanced across subjects and held constant across each testing session for each subject. For episodic memory task, this results in 12 task conditions (i.e., three task versions crossed with four enconcoding task ordering conditions). For working memory, this results in 4 task conditions (two N-Back difficulty block orders, crossed with two N-Back stimulus format orders) which are each yolked to an episodic condition.

Primary outcome measures will be cognitive task performance (episodic recollection accuracy, working memory accuracy) as a function of 3 key factors (age group, tDCS condition, and time-of-day) and their interaction, and also as a function of factors such as those obtained from wrist accelerometry sleep data, sleep diary/log data, and the Morningness-Eveningness Questionnaire (aka the Owl-Lark assessment).

q9.value: We will use RedCap software to randomize younger adults to one of the 3 arms (dlPFC tDCS, parietal tDCS, sham) and to randomize older adults to one of the 2 arms (dlPFC tDCS, sham). The research team interacting with the participants, the PI, and the participants will be blinded to conditions assignment, using a tDCS machine designed with arbitrary stimulation/sham codes for randomized double-blinded clinical trails (Solterix). A biostatistician who is a member of the Data Safety and Monitoring Board (DSMB), but not directly involved in participant testing, loads the stimulation and sham codes into RedCap for the research team to use when administering tDCS.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data collection and data analysis has begun already for this project, however the blinding codes that link a given participant to a stimulation condition (active vs. sham stimulation) have not been revealed and will not be revealed until data collection has been completed. Specifically, the analysis plan described in this preregistration was established and approved by the clinical trial DSMB prior to starting data collection. As part of our data quality checks, we have assessed summary data for the memory tasks, divided by age group, time of day, and expected task difficulty/materials manipulations. Importantly, we have not analyzed data broken by tDCS group, or possible interactions between tDCS group and age or time-of-day, as this aspect of the data is double-blinded and we plan to analyze assignment to tDCS group only after all data collection has been completed.

question.value:
Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria 
Participants must meet all of the inclusion criteria to participate in this study, and candidates meeting any of the exclusion criteria will be excluded from study participation:

  Inclusion Criteria:
Right-handed (according to the Edinburgh Handedness Inventory)
Normal or corrected vision
Fluent in English (started learning by age 6)
Ability to understand and provide informed consent for study procedures, and to comply - with study procedures for the entire length of the study.
 For individuals in the ‘younger adults’ group, must be between 18 and 30 years of age
For individuals in the ‘older adults’ group, must be between 60 and 75 years of age
A score of 23 or above on the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (out of 30, education-corrected) is required. This is to minimize the inclusion of suspected mild cognitive impairment (MCI) or dementia, targeting individuals that score in the normal range according to the recent meta-analysis of MoCA’s ability to differentiate normal aging from MCI in Carson et al. (2018, Int. J of Geriatric Psychiatry).
Performance above threshold on the episodic memory task during the baseline session. The threshold is defined as having a hit rate that is at least 5% greater than the false alarm rate, where hit rate is defined as the number of studied items identified as studied, divided by the total number of studied items, and false alarm rate is defined as the number of new items identified as studied, divided by the total number of new items. We don’t anticipate this threshold to exclude many  subjects.

 Exclusion Criteria:
Neuropsychological conditions associated with cognitive decline or seizure
Cochlear implants or metal in the brain/skull (except titanium)
Non-removable metal earrings or metal dental braces
 Psychoactive medications, diagnosis of depression, bipolar disorder, or any psychotic diagnoses
 History of excessive use (clinically treated) alcohol or narcotics
 Hospitalization for head trauma (e.g. concussions) in the past 5 years
 Individuals above a threshold score on an assessment of depression, specifically, a score of 10 or above on the PHQ-9 (Manea et al., 2012)
 Risk of pregnancy
 Low tolerance of skin irritation
 Prior brain stimulation experience (self-report)


 Study Enrollment Procedures 
Younger adults will be recruited from the University of Chicago (primarily students) and surrounding community, and older adults will be recruited from a database maintained by the Gallo lab, as well as newly recruited participants from the Chicago area using word-of-mouth and advertisements (e.g., Chicago Tribune). 
The Study Coordinator will recruit participants, and if they are eligible and wish to participate, use AM/PM Randomization REDCap database to assign them to have their AM session first or their PM session first. The participant will then be scheduled for all 3 sessions.
Participants will give informed consent for all 3 sessions during the baseline/study orientation day. All participants must consent for themselves. At this time they are considered enrolled.
Younger adults will be paid $10.00 for the first session, $20.00 for the second session and $40.00 for the final session. They can exchange $10.00 for one course credit, for up to three credits. 
Older adults will be paid $20.00 for the first session, $30.00 for the second session and $50.00 for the final session.

q14.value: Our power analysis was based on our most recent and largest tDCS experiment with younger adults (Wong et al., in press, n = 30 per each between-subjects condition), which yielded a 12% difference in word test accuracy between sham (.23, SD=.21) and active tDCS (.35, SD = .21) in the 9 AM group, predicting that we would need 50 participants in each stimulation group in order to obtain a similar effect size (Cohen’s d = .57, or a medium effect size) with 80% power at p<.05 (2 tailed, calculated with G-Power, v. 3.1.9.3). We therefore plan to test 50 younger adults and 50 older adults in each stimulation condition in order to detect effects of this magnitude. These sample sizes are considerably larger than most (if not all) of the between-subjects tDCS experiments on episodic memory published as of 2017. A sample size of 50 per condition also should yield sufficient power to detect the 2x2 interaction between brain stimulation (between-subjects) and time-of-day (within-subjects) in each age group, if we assume a similar effect size (partial eta squared = .06) for the interaction between time-of-day and stimulation we had obtained in younger adults in Wong et al. (in press), and also a .25  correlation between the repeated measures during AM and PM (80% power, alpha = .05).

q15.value:
The PI, in consultation with the DSMB, will temporarily suspend enrollment in the tDCS portions of the study if serious questions arise about efficacy, safety, or poor study performance (e.g., slow accrual, high losses-to-follow-up, and poor quality control). In this event, study enrollment will only recommence if DSMB and the PI agree that the issue(s) has been resolved, and make a designation that the study should (a) continue per protocol, (b) proceed with caution, (c) be further investigated, (d) be discontinued, or (e) be modified and then proceed. Given that tDCS is noninvasive, we do not expect this to happen.

    Examples of findings that might trigger a safety review are the number of SAEs overall, the number of occurrences of a particular type of SAE, severe AEs/reactions, or increased frequency of events. Such findings are presented to the DSMB statistician to review the events by group to determine whether there are statistical as well as clinical concerns. The statistician reports their findings to a closed session of the DSMB or to the Safety Officer and/or NIA. The findings are used to determine what steps will be taken.  Given that tDCS is noninvasive, we do not expect this to happen.

question.value: The primary manipulation is the tDCS stimulation condition. The stimulation condition (tDCS active vs. sham) is manipulated between-subjects, while time of testing (AM/PM) is manipulated within-subjects, and age (younger, older) is between-subjects. More specifically: 50 Younger Adults will be randomly assigned to three between-subjects tDCS conditions (left prefrontal active stimulation, left parietal active stimulation, left sham stimulation (½ prefrontal, ½ partietal), total YA n=150) and 50 cognitively normal older adults will be randomly assigned to two between-subject tDCS conditions (left prefrontal active, left sham prefrontal, total OA n=100).

- Memory performance - Our primary dependent variable (DV) will be accuracy on the episodic memory and working memory tasks. These will be assessed in each of the 3 sessions (baseline no-tDCS, AM tDCS, PM tDCS). For the episodic memory task, accuracy is defined as the proportion of studied items attributed to the correct source, minus the proportion of non-studied items incorrectly attributed to that source. For the working memory task, accuracy is defined as the proportion of targets correctly identified minus the proportion of lures incorrectly endorsed.

- Sleep quality (As measured by the wrist accelometry data)

- Time of day preference (as measured by the "Morningness Eveningness Questionaire", as well as wrist accelometry data

-Neuropsychological assessments  (MOCA - Montreal Cognitive Assessement, portion of the Shipley Assessement)

-Alertness ratings

- Demographics

- Substance intake (caffeine, nicotine, alcohol consumpition)

Primary Analyses Set 1 (1a, 1b, 1c). The first set of primary analyses will estimate the effect of tDCS to left dlPFC on cognitive performance and the extent to which different aspects of the cognitive task will be impacted. These analyses will be done separately for episodic and working memory. 

1.a This analysis will be done on younger adults only.  We shall use a linear mixed (i.e., random participant-level intercepts) model with memory performance (defined as memory accuracy computed by subtracting false alarms from target hits) as the dependent variable and stimulation condition (stimulation vs. sham), session Time of Day (AM, PM), and task manipulations (stimulus format and difficulty) as within-subjects predictors along with session order as a covariate (session 1, session 2). Interaction terms between stimulation condition and both task manipulation and time of day will be used to examine the impact of these variables on the stimulation effect.

1.b This analysis will use the same model as in 1a (above), but including data from both younger and older adults and a corresponding age-group factor in the model. Interaction terms between age group, stimulation condition, and time-of-day will be used to determine whether the overall stimulation effect is the same for older as for younger adults, and if not, whether the difference varies by time of day.

1.c This analysis will assess the impact of preferred time of day on tDCS effects, using wrist-worn (minimum 7-days, max 12-days) accelerometry to measure preferred time of day (i.e. “Owl” vs “Lark”), and validation using the subjective Morningness-Eveningness Questionnaire (MEQ). For this analysis, accelerometry-derived variables capturing preferred time of days (eg, including wake time, rise time and midpoint of sleep) will be added as covariates to the model in 1.b., and interactions between these, time of day and stimulation effects will be evaluated.



Set 2. The second set of primary analyses will focus on dlPFC vs parietal vs sham effects in younger adults only. For these analyses, similar models to those described above will be used (e.g., 1a, 1c, 2), except we will include 3 levels for tDCS (dlPFC, parietal, sham). We will test the relative fit of three models: (1) a model in which parietal has the same effect as sham, (2) a model in which parietal has the same effect as dlPFC, and (3) a model in which the effect of parietal differs from the other two conditions.

All analyses will initially be performed without using the baseline performance measures. We shall then repeat each analysis adjusting for the baseline value of the cognitive measure being analyzed. To the extent that the cognitive measures are highly correlated across timepoints, the latter analyses will provide additional power.

STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE

A two-sided p-value cutoff of 0.05 will be used for all null-hypothesis significance testing. In addition, point estimates for all first order and interaction effects will be reported, together with 95% confidence intervals. Between-individual contrasts (e.g., overall treatment effects) will be standardized (i.e., equivalent to Cohen’s d). Results of all analyses performed will be reported (not just those that meet the 0.05 cutoff). Since Hypotheses 1-4 are distinct, we shall not make any adjustment for multiple testing across the corresponding analyses. Within each analysis, we shall use a hierarchical approach in which we begin with an overall test of the null hypothesis at the coarsest level, separately for episodic and working memory, and only if that is statistically significant will we conduct further testing among subgroups.

Although the primary analyses will utilize the frequentist approach to estimating and testing, we will complement this with a secondary Bayesian analysis using the same model. For parameters capturing treatment effects or between-group differences in treatment effects (i.e., interaction terms), we shall use a weakly informative prior (e.g., Normal(0, 1-10)). The primary value of this analysis will be to provide more interpretable (i.e. probability) statements about the magnitude of the effects of tDCS and about the amount of information contained in the data.

SECONDARY ANALYSES
We will assess the impact of sleep quality for the prior night on tDCS effects, using wrist accelerometer data to measure sleep quality (eg, sleep fragmentation as total number of awakenings and sleep stage shifts divided by total sleep time, sleep efficiency as sleep duration divided by the time between the start and end of the first and last nocturnal inactivity period).  Sleep diaries will provide data missing from the objective measures, where applicable. For the analyses, we will conduct a linear mixed model identical to the ones already described, using sleep quality as a covariate.

q24.value: Exploratory analyses also will assess possible sex differences (male/female) in tDCS outcomes, as well as the possibility that tDCS may have more variable effects in young females due to possible interactions between menstrual phase and brain stimulation (analogous to similar interactions found with psychoactive stimulant amphetamine, see White et al. 2002). We are unaware of data from prior tDCS studies indicating different sized effects as a function of racial/ethnic subgroup, and although our study plans to have relatively large sample sizes for comparable tDCS studies of cognition, it is likely that we will have low statistical power to detect tDCS effects in racial/ethnic subgroups.

registration_responses.q1: Effect of Noninvasive Electrical Brain Stimulation on Memory Performance at Different Times of Day in Younger and Older Adults
registration_responses.q2: Gabriella V Hirsch, David A Gallo, Taylor Chamberlain, Gabriella Hirsch
registration_responses.q3: Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS) is a safe and accessible, non-invasive brain stimulation technique for testing causal links between different brain regions and functions.  However, the effectiveness of single-trial tDCS to manipulate higher-order cognitive functions, such as memory, is in question. This study will investigate the extent to which 20 minutes of anodal tDCS to left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (dlPFC), relative to a sham stimulation condition, impacts recollection accuracy and working memory performance as a function of time-of-day in younger and older adults. We also will include an active parietal stimulation control in younger adults. Moreover, this study will test the extent that tDCS to dlPFC impacts memory performance by modulating impacting information-specific processes and/or cognitive control processes that operate across different types of information, thereby informing basic theories of how dlPFC contributes to memory in younger and older adults.

1.  Younger Adults Primary Hypothesis: dlPFC tDCS/Sham X AM/PM. We hypothesize that tDCS benefits may be larger during suboptimal times of cognitive function. For younger adults, we predict that tDCS of the dlPFC will improve episodic memory accuracy and working memory, relative to sham tDCS or active parietal tDCS. We also predict larger tDCS benefits during the AM than PM session (i.e., the suboptimal time of cognitive function for many younger adults).

2. Older Adults Primary Hypothesis: dlPFC tDCS/Sham X AM/PM. We predict that tDCS of the dlPFC will improve episodic memory accuracy and working memory in older adults, relative to sham tDCS, with larger benefits during the PM session than the AM session (i.e., the suboptimal time of cognitive function for many older adults). 

3. Owl-Lark Hypotheses: tDCS effects may be moderated by time of day preferences, so in secondary analyses of tDCS effects we will assess tDCS effects as a function of an individual’s optimal time of processing (measured by self-report and wrist accelerometry) instead of age group. We predict larger tDCS benefits during suboptimal times of processing.

4. Task-based Hypotheses: To the extent that tDCS boosts memory by improving cognitively controlled processes, high difficulty items should benefit more from tDCS than low difficulty items on each memory task. To the extent that tDCS to left dlPFC boosts verbal/conceptual processing more than pictorial/visuospatial processing, the former should benefit more from tDCS than the latter.

registration_responses.q12.question:
Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria 
Participants must meet all of the inclusion criteria to participate in this study, and candidates meeting any of the exclusion criteria will be excluded from study participation:

  Inclusion Criteria:
Right-handed (according to the Edinburgh Handedness Inventory)
Normal or corrected vision
Fluent in English (started learning by age 6)
Ability to understand and provide informed consent for study procedures, and to comply - with study procedures for the entire length of the study.
 For individuals in the ‘younger adults’ group, must be between 18 and 30 years of age
For individuals in the ‘older adults’ group, must be between 60 and 75 years of age
A score of 23 or above on the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (out of 30, education-corrected) is required. This is to minimize the inclusion of suspected mild cognitive impairment (MCI) or dementia, targeting individuals that score in the normal range according to the recent meta-analysis of MoCA’s ability to differentiate normal aging from MCI in Carson et al. (2018, Int. J of Geriatric Psychiatry).
Performance above threshold on the episodic memory task during the baseline session. The threshold is defined as having a hit rate that is at least 5% greater than the false alarm rate, where hit rate is defined as the number of studied items identified as studied, divided by the total number of studied items, and false alarm rate is defined as the number of new items identified as studied, divided by the total number of new items. We don’t anticipate this threshold to exclude many  subjects.

 Exclusion Criteria:
Neuropsychological conditions associated with cognitive decline or seizure
Cochlear implants or metal in the brain/skull (except titanium)
Non-removable metal earrings or metal dental braces
 Psychoactive medications, diagnosis of depression, bipolar disorder, or any psychotic diagnoses
 History of excessive use (clinically treated) alcohol or narcotics
 Hospitalization for head trauma (e.g. concussions) in the past 5 years
 Individuals above a threshold score on an assessment of depression, specifically, a score of 10 or above on the PHQ-9 (Manea et al., 2012)
 Risk of pregnancy
 Low tolerance of skin irritation
 Prior brain stimulation experience (self-report)


 Study Enrollment Procedures 
Younger adults will be recruited from the University of Chicago (primarily students) and surrounding community, and older adults will be recruited from a database maintained by the Gallo lab, as well as newly recruited participants from the Chicago area using word-of-mouth and advertisements (e.g., Chicago Tribune). 
The Study Coordinator will recruit participants, and if they are eligible and wish to participate, use AM/PM Randomization REDCap database to assign them to have their AM session first or their PM session first. The participant will then be scheduled for all 3 sessions.
Participants will give informed consent for all 3 sessions during the baseline/study orientation day. All participants must consent for themselves. At this time they are considered enrolled.
Younger adults will be paid $10.00 for the first session, $20.00 for the second session and $40.00 for the final session. They can exchange $10.00 for one course credit, for up to three credits. 
Older adults will be paid $20.00 for the first session, $30.00 for the second session and $50.00 for the final session.
registration_responses.q16.question: The primary manipulation is the tDCS stimulation condition. The stimulation condition (tDCS active vs. sham) is manipulated between-subjects, while time of testing (AM/PM) is manipulated within-subjects, and age (younger, older) is between-subjects. More specifically: 50 Younger Adults will be randomly assigned to three between-subjects tDCS conditions (left prefrontal active stimulation, left parietal active stimulation, left sham stimulation (½ prefrontal, ½ partietal), total YA n=150) and 50 cognitively normal older adults will be randomly assigned to two between-subject tDCS conditions (left prefrontal active, left sham prefrontal, total OA n=100).
registration_responses.q17.question:
- Memory performance - Our primary dependent variable (DV) will be accuracy on the episodic memory and working memory tasks. These will be assessed in each of the 3 sessions (baseline no-tDCS, AM tDCS, PM tDCS). For the episodic memory task, accuracy is defined as the proportion of studied items attributed to the correct source, minus the proportion of non-studied items incorrectly attributed to that source. For the working memory task, accuracy is defined as the proportion of targets correctly identified minus the proportion of lures incorrectly endorsed.

- Sleep quality (As measured by the wrist accelometry data)

- Time of day preference (as measured by the "Morningness Eveningness Questionaire", as well as wrist accelometry data

-Neuropsychological assessments  (MOCA - Montreal Cognitive Assessement, portion of the Shipley Assessement)

-Alertness ratings

- Demographics

- Substance intake (caffeine, nicotine, alcohol consumpition)
registration_responses.q19.question:
Primary Analyses Set 1 (1a, 1b, 1c). The first set of primary analyses will estimate the effect of tDCS to left dlPFC on cognitive performance and the extent to which different aspects of the cognitive task will be impacted. These analyses will be done separately for episodic and working memory. 

1.a This analysis will be done on younger adults only.  We shall use a linear mixed (i.e., random participant-level intercepts) model with memory performance (defined as memory accuracy computed by subtracting false alarms from target hits) as the dependent variable and stimulation condition (stimulation vs. sham), session Time of Day (AM, PM), and task manipulations (stimulus format and difficulty) as within-subjects predictors along with session order as a covariate (session 1, session 2). Interaction terms between stimulation condition and both task manipulation and time of day will be used to examine the impact of these variables on the stimulation effect.

1.b This analysis will use the same model as in 1a (above), but including data from both younger and older adults and a corresponding age-group factor in the model. Interaction terms between age group, stimulation condition, and time-of-day will be used to determine whether the overall stimulation effect is the same for older as for younger adults, and if not, whether the difference varies by time of day.

1.c This analysis will assess the impact of preferred time of day on tDCS effects, using wrist-worn (minimum 7-days, max 12-days) accelerometry to measure preferred time of day (i.e. “Owl” vs “Lark”), and validation using the subjective Morningness-Eveningness Questionnaire (MEQ). For this analysis, accelerometry-derived variables capturing preferred time of days (eg, including wake time, rise time and midpoint of sleep) will be added as covariates to the model in 1.b., and interactions between these, time of day and stimulation effects will be evaluated.



Set 2. The second set of primary analyses will focus on dlPFC vs parietal vs sham effects in younger adults only. For these analyses, similar models to those described above will be used (e.g., 1a, 1c, 2), except we will include 3 levels for tDCS (dlPFC, parietal, sham). We will test the relative fit of three models: (1) a model in which parietal has the same effect as sham, (2) a model in which parietal has the same effect as dlPFC, and (3) a model in which the effect of parietal differs from the other two conditions.

All analyses will initially be performed without using the baseline performance measures. We shall then repeat each analysis adjusting for the baseline value of the cognitive measure being analyzed. To the extent that the cognitive measures are highly correlated across timepoints, the latter analyses will provide additional power.

STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE

A two-sided p-value cutoff of 0.05 will be used for all null-hypothesis significance testing. In addition, point estimates for all first order and interaction effects will be reported, together with 95% confidence intervals. Between-individual contrasts (e.g., overall treatment effects) will be standardized (i.e., equivalent to Cohen’s d). Results of all analyses performed will be reported (not just those that meet the 0.05 cutoff). Since Hypotheses 1-4 are distinct, we shall not make any adjustment for multiple testing across the corresponding analyses. Within each analysis, we shall use a hierarchical approach in which we begin with an overall test of the null hypothesis at the coarsest level, separately for episodic and working memory, and only if that is statistically significant will we conduct further testing among subgroups.

Although the primary analyses will utilize the frequentist approach to estimating and testing, we will complement this with a secondary Bayesian analysis using the same model. For parameters capturing treatment effects or between-group differences in treatment effects (i.e., interaction terms), we shall use a weakly informative prior (e.g., Normal(0, 1-10)). The primary value of this analysis will be to provide more interpretable (i.e. probability) statements about the magnitude of the effects of tDCS and about the amount of information contained in the data.

SECONDARY ANALYSES
We will assess the impact of sleep quality for the prior night on tDCS effects, using wrist accelerometer data to measure sleep quality (eg, sleep fragmentation as total number of awakenings and sleep stage shifts divided by total sleep time, sleep efficiency as sleep duration divided by the time between the start and end of the first and last nocturnal inactivity period).  Sleep diaries will provide data missing from the objective measures, where applicable. For the analyses, we will conduct a linear mixed model identical to the ones already described, using sleep quality as a covariate.

attributes.title: The effect of added mass and handgrip on maximal power output in sprint cycling

q1.value: The effect of added mass and handgrip on maximal power output in sprint cycling

q2.value: Ross D. Wilkinson, Glen A. Lichtwark

q3.value: It has been shown that maximal power output is ~8-15% higher in a non-seated posture compared to when seated (Resier et al., 2002; Hug et al., 2011, Driss and Vandewalle, 2013). Evidence suggests the increase in maximal power when using a non-seated posture is due to a greater contribution of power from muscles in the upper body (Davidson et al., 2005 (Pilot study)). This evidence is supported by the finding that riders activate their upper body muscles during high-power output cycling to a greater level in a non-seated posture compared to when seated (Turpin et al., 2017). It has been proposed that this upper body muscle activity is to prevent upward acceleration of the rider's centre of mass, which allows leg extension power to generate greater levels of crank power (Dore et al., 2006). Further insight has been provided recently by the finding that riders raise and lower their centre of mass during specific phases of the crank cycle to amplify instantaneous maximal crank power when cycling in a non-seated posture (Wilkinson et al., unpublished data). The purpose of this study is to quantify the contribution of upper body muscular and non-muscular power to maximal power output during sprint cycling in both a seated and non-seated posture.

q4.value: If muscles in the upper body contribute more power during non-seated sprinting compared to seated, then the effect of gripping the handlebar on maximal power output should be significantly greater during non-seated cycling compared to when seated. If the mass of the upper body amplifies crank power during non-seated cycling, then peak instantaneous crank power should be significantly greater when mass is added to the torso of the rider.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Repeated measures within-subject design with 2 factors (torso mass and handlebar grip) and 2 levels each (torso mass: no added mass and 20% additional mass. handlebar grip: no grip and grip).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will recruited through word of mouth. Participants will not be paid for agreeing to participate. Participants must be at least 18 years old and be able to perform high-intensity exercise.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 16 participants. We attempt to recruit up to 20, assuming that not all will complete the total task or that some data may be lost due to technical issues.

question.value: The single outcome variable will be the instantaneous maximal power output produced by each participant during a maximal sprint on a bicycle ergometer. We will measure this using instrumented cranks that measure force and crank angle at up to 500 Hz.
We will use a 3 x 2 repeated measures ANOVA (RMANOVA) with all three factors within subjects to analyze our results.

q1.value: The Effects of Exercise on the Fasting Ketone Production Curve: A Randomized Crossover Study

q3.value:
Because of the potential health benefits that come from being in a state of ketosis, we aim to evaluate ketone production during a 36-hour fast and evaluate how exercise influences this production. Mood, hunger, physical activity, and sleep will also be evaluated to measure their influence on participants’ perception of fasting.  
We expect to see a significant difference in the area under the curve when comparing the ketone levels between the two conditions.

q4.value:
H1 – The area under the ketone production curve will be higher during the exercise condition compared to the non-exercise condition over the course of a 36-hour fast.  

H2 – Tension, depression, anger, fatigue, and confusion will increase, while vigor will decrease, throughout the exercise day compared to the non-exercise day while fasting.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A randomized crossover design with counterbalanced treatment conditions will be used to compare the influence of fasting alone to fasting combined with vigorous exercise on the ketone production curve within subjects.

q9.value: Using randomizer.org, condition order will be randomly assigned to participant numbers prior to the study. The participant number will be assigned to the participants chronologically from the time they join the study.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Subjects will be recruited through word of mouth, advertisements, and fliers in the local community. Participants will be adults who are 18 years of age or older and must be weight stable for the past 3 months.  Participants will be required to participate in vigorous physical activity without restrictions as measured by a physical activity readiness questionnaire (PAR-Q). The PAR-Q contains questions regarding contraindications to physical activity. Exclusion will also occur if participants do not provide proper written consent or if they meet any of the following exclusion criteria: 

Diagnosed with a chronic disease (i.e.- cancer, heart/liver/kidney disease) 

Diagnosed with a metabolic disease (i.e.- Type I and Type II diabetes) 

Diagnosed with orthopedic impairments (i.e.- joint replacements or arthritis) 

Diagnosed with an eating disorder (i.e.- anorexia, bulimia or binge eating disorder) 

Taking medications that alter metabolism, appetite or neurological function (i.e.- insulin, metformin, amphetamine-based ADHD medications, depression and anxiety medications such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, serotonin and norepinephrine inhibitors and benzodiazepines)

Food allergies (i.e.- nuts, celiac disease or gluten intolerance, or lactose intolerance) 

Habitually consume 60 mg or more of caffeine daily  

Pregnant or lactating 

Post-menopausal

Underweight or obese (BMI <18.5 or >30 or a bodyweight of less than 110 lbs.)

Currently participating in ketogenic, carbohydrate or calorie-restricted diets 

Currently fasting more than once per week 

Irregular sleeping patterns (including graveyard or swing shifts)

q13.value: Recruiting will continue until thirty healthy adults (15 female and 15 male) complete all aspects of this study.  Because of the crossover design, each participant will complete both interventions, giving a total of sixty units.

q14.value: The sample size for this study was estimated based on a meaningful difference in ketone production curves within subjects.  Based on pilot work, the standard deviation of time-to-ketosis was set at 3 hours. We conservatively estimated the correlation (r) between a person's time-to-ketosis when exercising vs. not exercising to be 0.8 and the difference between the two conditions for the time-to-ketosis was set to 1 hour. Using these values and setting alpha to 0.05, a sample of 30 participants is needed to yield a 95% power.  Participants will be recruited until 30 people have completed the study.

question.value:
A standardized meal will be given to each participant to initiate each fasting period.  Meals will be standardized based on macronutrient content (60% CHO, 25% fat, 15% protein). Participants will be given 25% (BMR x 1.55 x 0.25) of their daily caloric requirements in the standardized meal.  The same foods will be given on both test days and participants will be instructed to consume all the food provided for each meal.  Meal adherence will be assessed in each session by direct observation by the researchers.  Any non-compliance (not eating all food and/or eating other foods) will require participants to redo that particular lab session on a different day when they have followed food protocols.  Meals are designed to represent a reasonable amount of food to provide participants with adequate food intake.

Based on random assignment, a participant will either complete a treadmill exercise at the beginning of a fasting period or be dismissed following their standardized meal. During the exercise intervention, participants will jog on a treadmill at a grade and speed that brings their estimated heart rate reserve (HRR) to 70%.  Participants will exercise in this manner until an equivalent number of calories is expended as given in the standardized meal.

Weight and height will be measured for all participants at the beginning of each lab visit.   
A GE iDXA (GE, Fairfield, CT) will be used to assess fat-free mass, fat mass, lean mass, percent body fat, and visceral adipose tissue.
Participants will be asked to rate their mood and energy levels using the Brunel Mood Scale (BRUMS), every 2 hours while recording capillary ketone levels.
Two 5ml EDTA (with anti-coagulant) tubes of blood will be taken from each participant via venipuncture for analysis of blood ketone and glucose levels. These will be taken every 12 hours during the fasting periods.  
Capillary ketone measurements will be assessed on the even hours during the fasting session (with the exception of sleep time) using the Precision Xtra portable ketone meter.
The ActiGraph GT3X accelerometer will be used to objectively measure physical activity. The accelerometer will be worn on the non-dominant wrist.
Sleep will be assessed by actigraphy using the ActiGraph GT3X activity monitor. Sleep log data will be used to verify sleep and wake times, and actigraph data will be used for data analysis.

Analyses will be completed using SAS statistical software (version 9.4; SAS Institute, Inc. Cary NC).  Participant data will be reported as means and standard deviations. To evaluate the difference in the area under the ketone curve, a repeated-measures mixed-effects analysis of variance will be used.  Similarly, repeated measures mixed effects ANOVA will be used to assess the differences in time to ketosis between conditions. Repeated measures mixed effects ANOVA will also be utilized to assess the impact of fasting on mood and hunger over the course of the day of fasting for each condition.  An alpha level of 0.05 will be used for this analysis.  Least squared means procedure will be used to assess the main and interactive effects.  Condition and gender will be the primary factors in the model.  The two conditions being considered are fasting without exercise and fasting with exercise.  The variables to be controlled are visceral adiposity, fasting history, and BMI.

q22.value: We will verify that each data point is valid and provide an explanation for abnormal data points. Outliers will be included in the analysis.

attributes.title: A Scoping Review of Selected Sexually Transmitted Infections in Active Duty US Military Women

summary.value: This is a second addendum to our original PRISMA-ScR checklist registration. The original PRISMA checklist was registered on 2/26/19 at the following doi: 10.17605/OSF.IO/JVGD5. Addendum #1 was registered on 4/12/19 at the following doi: 10.17605/OSF.IO/RGF6S. The current status of the project is that the articles have been screened and data charted. Changes to the PRISMA checklist for this addendum are in red font in the attached PDF and are described as follows. The original objective was “to conduct a scoping review of the literature to examine sexually transmitted infections in Active Duty US military women”. The objective was revised in this addendum to the following: “The objective of this scoping review is to apply the Social Ecological Model for Military Women’s Health (SEM-MWH) to the available literature to determine what is known about United States military women (population) and the risk factors, preventive measures, and health outcomes (context) in regards to sexually transmitted infections (concept).”

registration_responses.summary: This is a second addendum to our original PRISMA-ScR checklist registration. The original PRISMA checklist was registered on 2/26/19 at the following doi: 10.17605/OSF.IO/JVGD5. Addendum #1 was registered on 4/12/19 at the following doi: 10.17605/OSF.IO/RGF6S. Changes to the PRISMA checklist for this addendum are in red font in the attached PDF and are described as follows. The original objective was “to conduct a scoping review of the literature to examine sexually transmitted infections in Active Duty US military women”. The objective was revised in this addendum to the following: “The objective of this scoping review is to apply the Social Ecological Model for Military Women’s Health (SEM-MWH) to the available literature to determine what is known about United States military women (population) and the risk factors, preventive measures, and health outcomes (context) in regards to sexually transmitted infections (concept).”

summary.value: This is a second addendum to our original PRISMA-ScR checklist registration. The original PRISMA checklist was registered on 2/26/19 at the following doi: 10.17605/OSF.IO/JVGD5. Addendum #1 was registered on 4/12/19 at the following doi: 10.17605/OSF.IO/RGF6S. The current status of the project is that the articles have been screened and data charted. Changes to the PRISMA checklist for this addendum are in red font in the attached PDF and are described as follows.
